--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Mohr (Internet Archive)" 
<gojomo@a...> wrote:
> Can you explain the rules you use to coerce URIs into
> acceptable filenames?

There are several knobs you can turn, but basically the steps are
1) Replace special characters.
2) Truncate each path segment (component) to fit file system
   limits.
3) When needed, append a sequential number to make files
   unique.


> Is the process completely deterministic -- without consulting
> what's already in the target directory?

In general, each file system path depends on both the URI and on
the files that already exist.  For example, suppose the file system
is case-insensitive.  First http://acme.com/goodstuff/a.zip and
then http://acme.com/GoodStuff/a.zip is crawled.  This will result
in the directories goodstuff and GoodStuff1, each containing an
a.zip file.  If the URIs were crawled in the opposite order, the
directories GoodStuff and goodstuff1 would instead result.


> I think it might be possible to make a Javascript-based local-files
> Wayback Machine -- that loads the local file into a frame (or IFRAME),
> patches the inline resource URIs dynamically (like the public Wayback
> Machine), and captures any attempts to browse outside the frame,
> redirecting it back to the captured local files. If the
> Javascript and the captured files are both coming from the same local
> disks, it should be able to do all the necessary steps, without
> ever changing the files themselves.
>
> - Gordon @ IA

Ingenious.
